awd_titl_txt: Corpus and lexicon development: Endangered genres of discourse and domains of cultural knowledge in Tu'un isavi (Mixtec) of Yoloxochitl, Guerrero
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will produce and use extensive primary documentation (over 100 hours of digital recordings and time-coded transcriptions) to analyze the phonetics, phonology, and morphosyntax of Yoloxóchitl Mixtec (YM), a little-studied, isolated Mixtecan verb-initial language spoken by 15,000 people in four villages within a 12 kilometer radius in coastal Guerrero, Mexico. The complex phonetics and phonology of Mixtecan languages (floating tones, sandhi, and the diversity of tonal sequences on the bimoraic tone-bearing-unit) is of significant theoretical interest. YM is noteworthy for its inventory of 5 tone levels and 18 sequences on the bimoraic tone bearing unit. Nasalization in Mixtecan languages has also attracted significant interest and here too YM is unusual in that nasal vowels are limited to word-final syllables. Syllable-initial vowels in disyllabic stems are never nasal. Finally, the acoustics of stress has received little attention in Mixtecan studies although the nature of stress in tonal languages is a complex topic of considerable theoretical concern. These and other topics in YM phonetics and phonology will be studied by an interdisciplinary research team, including a native speaker with a masters degree in linguistics and a team of phoneticians and phonologists.

Like other Mixtecan languages, YM is verb initial, a basic word order sequence represented in only approximately ten percent of world languages. This project will provide a detailed morphosyntactical study of this unusual type and address specific research questions, such as the pragmatic and discourse implications of nonbasic word order. The development of both an extensive corpus of transcribed natural recordings and elicitation material targeting specific questions in YM morphology and syntax will provide an unusually rich set of materials for linguistic research.  In sum, this project will provide extensive primary documentation and establish an analytical base for future linguistic studies, particularly in phonetics, phonology, and morphosyntax, areas in which YM is of typological interest.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Although the Documenting Endangered Language program of the National Science Foundation targets the creation of digitally archived material on languages that are on the verge of being lost, the ultimate goal is to provide scientists from a wide range of disciplines with primary data that they can use to further their own research. This is not a trivial task as it is often difficult for the principal investigator of the documentation project to assemble material from a dying language that will be sufficiently complete and transparent to enable other researchers to utilize the archived materials to good effect. The present project has benefited from collaboration with three other NSF-funded projects, all of which utilized the Mixtec material that has resulted from the "Corpus and lexicon development" effort: (1) an extensive corpus of digital audio and video recordings, all transcribed and annotated, and many translated; (2) the framework of a dictionary with over 2,500 entries and double that amount of subentries; (3) grammatical notes on Yoloxochitl Mixtec phonology and morphology. The collaboration took place as the "Corpus and lexicon development" project was active and thus served as a way to evaluate and re-evaluate how language documentation projects need to develop and archive their material results so that other researchers will be able to discover and use them. Included among the collaborations was a project that pioneered automated speech recognition for the endangered language, Yoloxochitl Mixtec, that presented problems not often found in the major languages for which such tools are usually developed. Three US undergraduate students and two graduates participated in these collaborative ventures.

In addition to the aforementioned collaboration with other NSF-supported projects, "Corpus and lexicon development" also reached across disciplinary boundaries. With financial support from a Mexican government institution, an extensive study of traditional Yoloxochitl Mixtec knowledge (names, classification, and use) of local plants was carried out over the course of a year. This resulted in over 1,250 collections of plants, many of which were named and used Yoloxochitl Mixtec consultants. A professor of entomology and his undergraduate student also worked on this project, providing the scientific names of insects that they collected, names that are essential to understanding the meaning of Yoloxochitl Mixtec terms for these insects.

In sum, the linguistic, ethnographic, and biological material that this project has produced has already had an impact on scientific research in various fields.

 

BROADER IMPACT

As already mentioned, the " Corpus and lexicon development" project has worked collaboratively with other NSF-support projects, collaborations that involved the training of both undergraduate and graduate students in linguistics, computer science, and biology. It has served to promote international collaboration not only between US and Mexican students and scientists but between US and Mexican institutions, particularly herbaria and biology institutes and departments.

The project has also developed audio-visual material that will continue to be developed. As this occurs it will be disseminated to the general public via a Vimeo channel (https://vimeo.com/channels/1223182) and, later, a parallel YouTube outlet. The videos will cover both secular and ritual activities in Yoloxochitl including many of ancient and seldom documented prayers.

Finally, the ethnobiological material that this project has developed will be made available to the general public though a data portal that the PI is presently developing with funding from the National Endowment for the Humanities. This portal (demca.sites.gettysburg.edu) hopefully will eventually serve to disseminate aspects of the traditional ecological knowledge of Indigenous communities in Mexico and Central America.
